citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
The licensee stated that 2 guinea baboons were purchased from an individual in Seagoville, TX on August 25, 2025 and
the seller does not have a USDA license. Animals sold by individuals who are required to have a USDA license, but does
not a valid USDA license may suffer from poor welfare due to lack of compliance with Animal Welfare Act (AWA)
regulations. No dealer or exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other animal from any person who is required to
be licensed, but who does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license.
Documented on 30 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 30 SEPT 2025

An olive baboon was observed chewing on hair tie inside its enclosure. Ingestion of the material could potentially cause
injury to the animal. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so that they are
structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, and they
must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
Corrected at time of inspection 29 SEPT 2025
A white headed capuchin was observed reaching outside his primary enclosure flipping open the covers for an electrical
outlet. The opened electrical outlet is a potential source of injury to the animals. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates
must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in
them. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and
restrict other animals from entering.
Documented during inspection on 29 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 03 OCT 2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the primary enclosures for the ring tailed lemurs, there were many rats seen inside the enclosure with the nonhuman
primates. The presence of rats is a potential disease hazard to the animals as these rodents can be carriers of disease
and parasites. An effective program for control of mammals that are pests, must be established and maintained so as to
promote the health and well-being of animals and reduce contamination by pests in the animal areas.
Documented on 29 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 13 OCT 2025

In the large outdoor enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, sheep, and zebra, there are several
railroad ties that have metal rods with sharp points exposed to the animals. This is a potential source of injury to the
enclosed animals. The railroad ties with sharp extending rods need to be removed. All housing facilities shall be
structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.132(d)  Critical
   
Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers. 
The licensee stated that 2 guinea baboons were purchased from an individual in Seagoville, TX on August 25, 2025 and 
the seller does not have a USDA license. Animals sold by individuals who are required to have a USDA license, but does 
not a valid USDA license may suffer from poor welfare due to lack of compliance with Animal Welfare Act (AWA) 
regulations. No dealer or exhibitor shall knowingly obtain any dog, cat, or other animal from any person who is required to 
be licensed, but who does not hold a current, valid, and unsuspended license.  
 
Documented on 30 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 30 SEPT 2025 
3.75(a)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
An olive baboon was observed chewing on hair tie inside its enclosure. Ingestion of the material could potentially cause 
injury to the animal. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so that they are 
structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, and they 
must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. 
 
Corrected at time of inspection 29 SEPT 2025 
 
A white headed capuchin was observed reaching outside his primary enclosure flipping open the covers for an electrical 
outlet. The opened electrical outlet is a potential source of injury to the animals. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates 
must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in 
them. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and 
restrict other animals from entering. 
 
Documented during inspection on 29 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 03 OCT 2025 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

In the primary enclosures for the ring tailed lemurs, there were many rats seen inside the enclosure with the nonhuman 
primates. The presence of rats is a potential disease hazard to the animals as these rodents can be carriers of disease 
and parasites. An effective program for control of mammals that are pests, must be established and maintained so as to 
promote the health and well-being of animals and reduce contamination by pests in the animal areas.  
 
Documented on 29 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 13 OCT 2025 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In the large outdoor enclosure housing sika deer, blackbuck, fallow deer, goats, sheep, and zebra, there are several 
railroad ties that have metal rods with sharp points exposed to the animals. This is a potential source of injury to the 
enclosed animals. The railroad ties with sharp extending rods need to be removed. All housing facilities shall be 
structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
